PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The Government of Mongolia (GOM) requested support through (i) consultations with ADB 
staff, (ii) a letter from the Ministry of Environment and Green Development (MEGD) on 11 March 
2013, and (iii) a letter from Ministry of Economic Development on 25 April 2013 for the preparation 
of  the Tuul  River  Improvement  Project. To facilitate  the  preparation of  the  project,  a  project 
preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) of $1 million will be provided by the Japan Fund for 
Poverty Reduction, administered by ADB. 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
 
2.  The major outputs of the PPTA will be: (i) a project design which responds to government's 
needs and fulfill ADB requirements, and (ii) detailed data collection and surveys. Specifically, the 
outputs  include  (i)  sector  assessment;  (ii)  financial  management  and  procurement  capacity 
assessments; (iii) stakeholder analysis, and problems and constraints identification; (iv) a project 
technical, environmental, economic, financial and social appraisal; (v) a participatory gender plan 
and a sustainable livelihood plan; (vi) a resettlement plan, if required; (vii) initial environmental 
examination and management plans; and (viii) an institutional and capacity development plan.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement

on  a grant  basis  by  the  Japan  Fund for  Poverty  Reduction,  and  administered  by  ADB. The 
government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, data collection, office 
facilities, administrative support, and other in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimate is

D.  Consulting Services 
 
5.  It is expected that a consulting firm will be recruited. ADB will be responsible for recruiting 
consultants following ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to 
time). A consulting firm will be recruited using the quality- and cost-based selection (QCBS) at a 
quality–cost ratio of 80:20 using simplified technical proposal.

6.  The outline terms of reference for the PPTA consultants are described in paras. 7 to 21. 
 
A.  PPTA Consulting Firm 
 
7.  Water  resources  management  specialist  and  team  leader  [international,  9  person-
months  (pm)]. The specialist  will  have  a  master’s  degree  or  equivalent qualification  in  water 
resources  management,  and  at  least  5  years  of  experience  in  formulating  donor  funding 
investment  projects.  The  specialist  will  have  overall  responsibility  for  effective  and  timely 
implementation of the PPTA and quality of all outputs, and coordinating and consolidating inputs of 
government agencies and other specialists.  
 
8.  Groundwater resources monitoring specialist (international, 3 pm). The specialist will 
preferably  have  a  master’s  degree  in  groundwater  resources  management  or  equivalent 
qualifications,  and  at  least  8  year  work  experience  with  artificial  groundwater  recharge.  The 
specialist will (i) conduct a brief assessment of experiences on successful groundwater recharge 
and  ecological  restoration  approaches  in  Mongolia;  (ii)  summarize  groundwater  recharge 
opportunities  in  the Tuul  River  Basin,  including  ecological  restoration  programs  (wetland  and 
floodplains) that to promote groundwater recharge; and (iii) design the groundwater recharge 
investments to be included in the project. 
 
9.  Hydraulic engineer (international, 2 pm). The specialist will have bachelor’s degree in 
hydraulic engineering and over 10 years of experience in designing hydraulic engineering projects. 
The specialist, in close cooperation with the national hydraulic engineer, will be responsible for the 
design and quality control of the hydraulic structures proposed for the investment project. 
 
10.  Environment and ecological specialist (international, 2 pm). The specialist will have a 
master’s  degree  or  equivalent  qualification  in  environmental  studies  and  at  least  8  years  of 
experience  in  environmental  assessment  and  ecological  sciences.  The  specialist,  in  close 
cooperation with the national environment specialist, will (i) assess possible environmental impacts 
of each project activity, including livelihood impacts through environmental media; (ii) coordinate 
and supervise the development of the national environmental reporting requirements; (iii) prepare 
an  initial  environmental  examination  which  complies  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement 
(2009) requirements; and (iv) prepare a communications strategy. 
 
11.  Sediment pollution specialist (international, 1 pm). The specialist will have a master’s 
degree or equivalent qualification in environmental studies and at least 8 years of experience in 
soil or sediment pollution control. The specialist will (i) assess the pollution status of selected 
stretches of the Tuul River, (ii) identify opportunities for clean-up and disposal of the sediments, 
and (iii) contribute to the project design. 
 
12.  Social development and resettlement specialist (international, 2 pm). The specialist will 
have a master’s degree or equivalent qualification in social development studies and at least 8 
years of experience in social development studies and IFI social safeguard policies. The specialist 
will be responsible for (i) conducting a poverty and social analysis; (ii) formulating action for social

inclusion and gender equity; (iii) preparing a participation strategy; (iv) confirm social safeguards 
categorizations;  and  (v)  prepare,  if  necessary,  social  safeguard  documents,  including  a 
resettlement plan or an ethnic minority development plan.  
 
13.  Environmental economist (international, 2 pm). The economist will have a bachelor’s 
degree in economics, and at least 8 years of work experience in economic analyses of ADB- or 
other projects financed by multilateral development banks related to environment and natural 
resources management. The economist will (i) prepare the economic analysis of the project in 
accordance with ADB's Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Project ADB guidelines, (ii) design 
the development and implementing of economic instruments for pollution control, and (iii) provide 
support to the national financial specialist. The economic analysis will include at least cost analysis, 
cost-benefit  analysis,  sensitivity  and  risk  analysis,  distribution  analysis,  and  financial  and 
institutional sustainability analysis.  
 
14.  Water resources specialist and deputy team leader (national, 10 pm). The specialist and 
deputy team leader will have a bachelor’s degree or equivalent qualification in water resources 
management or other related fields and at least 5 years of work experience in formulating foreign 
funded projects. The specialist will support the international team leader to ensure the effective and 
timely implementation of the PPTA and be responsible for the coordination and reviewing of the 
design and quality control for output 1, which focuses on groundwater management.  
 
15.  Institutional  water  expert  (national, 2 pm). The expert will preferably have a master 
degree in water resources management or relevant field, and at least 7 years of work experience in 
water management policies. The specialist will (i) support executing and implementing agencies 
with reviewing technical and institutional aspects of the proposed project; and (ii) provide training 
on technical and institutional issues, as needed.  
 
16.  Hydraulic  engineer  (national,  8  pm).  The  specialist  will  have  a  bachelor’s  degree  in 
hydraulic engineering and over 5 years of experience in designing hydraulic engineering projects. 
The specialist will specifically be responsible for the design and quality control of all investments 
that involves hydraulic engineering.  
 
17.  Water information management specialist (national, 6 pm). The specialist will preferably 
have a master’s degree in water resources management, computer application, or relevant fields, 
and at least 7 years of work experience in developing water information and monitoring systems. 
The specialist will be responsible for the design and preparation of the proposed investments for 
the water monitoring network. 
 
18.  Environment specialist (national, 8 pm). The specialist will have a bachelor’s degree or 
equivalent qualification in environmental studies and at least 5 years of experience in conducting 
environmental assessment. The specialist will support the international environment and ecological 
specialist to (i) assess possible environmental impacts, and (ii) prepare an initial environmental 
examination which complies with ADB requirements. 
 
19.  Social  development  specialist (national, 8 pm). The specialist will have a bachelor’s 
degree or relevant qualification in social sciences and/or development studies and at least 5 years 
of work experience in social development studies. The specialist will support the international 
social development and resettlement specialist to (i) conduct a poverty and social analysis; (ii) 
formulating action for social inclusion and gender equity; (iii) preparing a participation strategy; (iv) 
confirm  social  safeguards  categorizations;  and  (v)  prepare,  if  necessary,  social  safeguards 
documents, including a resettlement plan or an ethnic minority development plan. 
 
20.  Financial specialist (national, 6 pm). The specialist will have (i) a bachelor’s degree in 
accounting,  finance,  or  financial  management;  (ii)  a  recognized  professional  accountancy

5 
qualification (e.g., CPA); and (iii) at least 5 years of experience in project financial management 
assessment. The specialist will (i) prepare project costs in cooperation with team leader and deputy 
team  leader,  (ii)  conduct  a  financial  management  assessment  (FMA)  of  the  executing  and 
implementing agencies, and (iii) conduct financial sustainability analysis required for non-revenue 
generating projects. The FMA should consider (i) the design of the funds flow and disbursement 
mechanisms for the ensuing project, based on the FMA of executing and implementing agencies; 
and (ii) identify any further capacity development (financial management and ADB’s disbursement 
procedures) that will be necessary for the project.  
 
21.  Procurement and project management specialist (national, 6 pm). The specialist will 
have a bachelor’s degree in engineering and at least 5 years of experience in project management, 
procurement,  and  consulting  services.  The  specialist  will  (i)  conduct  procurement  capacity 
assessment  for  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  to  undertake  procurement  and 
consultant recruitments envisaged under the project, (ii) conduct a market analysis, (iii) prepare a 
procurement plan, (iv) provide training for the executing and implementing agencies on ADB’s 
procurement  procedures,  (v)  support  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  with  project 
management tasks, (vi) provide training on the management and implementation of ADB funding 
projects, and (vii) support the executing and implementing agencies in project design. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
22.  The  MEGD  will  be  the  executing  agency  for  the  PPTA  and  serve  as  focal  point  for 
coordinating the preparation and implementation of the PPTA implementation and the ensuing 
proposed project. The TRBA will be the implementing agency. A PMO, chaired by the MEGD, will 
be established in the TRBA and will comprise staff from the MEGD and TRBA. The PMO will 
provide oversight and ensure coordination across sectors and provide guidance to the project 
preparation and implementation. A PPTA steering committee, comprising of representatives of the 
relevant key government agencies, will be established to provide oversight and coordination. The 
proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). Procurement for the TA will be conducted in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement Guidelines  (2013,  as  amended from time to  time).  The 
equipment will be handed over to MEGD upon the completion of the PPTA.  
 
23.  The PPTA will be implemented over a period of 15 months tentatively from 1 January 2014 
until 31 March 2015. The proposed PPTA processing and implementation schedule is listed in 
Table A4.4.
